summary: Commodus (Joaquin Phoenix) takes power and strips rank from Maximus (Russell Crowe), one of the favored generals of his predecessor and father, Emperor Marcus Aurelius, the great stoical philosopher. Maximus is then relegated to fighting to the death in the gladiator arenas.

The big screen Roman Epic comes roaring back to life in Ridley Scott's rousing film. Scott has few peers when it comes to bringing scale and scope to a movie, and this is some of his finest work. It's a brilliant mix of superb production design (costumes, art direction, sets) and immersive location shooting in Morocco, Italy, and the UK. Special effects fill in the gaps and help sell us on the spectacular sights of the vast reach of the Roman Empire. Russell Crowe is a riveting center to this, anchoring the film in his stoic presence and battlefield credibility (he looks perfectly at-home on a horse). Joaquin Phoenix brings shades of gray to his impetuous ruler, an emperor-with-no-clothes hiding his cowardice behind a veil ruthless ambition and populism. Connie Nielsen does well as a woman navigating a complex situation, simultaneously working to appease, flatter and placate her at times incestuous mad king brother, while carefully threading the needle to what may be an attempted coup. The late Oliver Reed brought a touch of the grand to his role, Djimon Honsou is solid support, and David Hemmings had the theatrical voice and over-the-top eyebrows to embody the master of ceremonies of the gladiator matches. Those fights--complete with chariots, horses, and even tigers, taking place in the grand Colosseum--and the battlefield scenes are brutal blurs of grim beauty, bringing the immediacy and savagery of up-close combat to vivid life. The films loses some steam in the palace and political intrigues, and as history this is just hooey, despite all the attention to detail. And ultimately, the plot boils down to a revenge tale. While it may not reach the cinematic heights of epic filmmaking, a la David Lean or John Ford, Scott still puts on a hell of a show, a grand cinematic spectacle that demands to be seen and experienced on the big screen

Gladiator is a true modern epic, drawing heavily on Spartacus but reshuffling narrative elements for an original story. Russell Crowe is fantastic, one of his best roles ever. The action is gripping and brutal. Hans Zimmer's score evokes feelings of some heavenly afterlife. Considering the historical reality of the brutal politics of ancient Rome, on a rewatch I found the ending a bit too "Hollywood", with everything being resolved and a nice bow placed on top. But still, this is meant to be a completely fictional story (although placed in a semi-accurate historical setting, with fictional versions of some historical figures), so I can't get too upset at any inconsistencies with reality. It feels more inspired by mythology and the swords and sandals epics of the 50's & 60's, then it is by any historical commitment.

Gladiador es una cinta épica y muy bien dirigida por Ridley Scott, un clásico bastante referenciado en la cultura popular y que a decir verdad, funciona bastante bien. Gladiador nos entrega peleas épicas que merecen todos los halagos, pero mas que la acción emocionante que nos ofrece, es una historia de honor, libertad y moral. Es un logro técnico espectacular en cuanto a lo que confiere la edición, fotografía, efectos visuales y la grabación y edición del sonido que es exquisito y excitante; sin embargo posee un guion defectuoso lo cual es lo mas decepcionante y que arruina totalmente la película dado que A VECES es predecible, tedioso, con agujeros y fallos argumentales que retrae algo de la emoción y epicidad de la película. los personajes, si, sus motivaciones son claras, son simpatizantes, están bien explicadas sus personalidades, pero sin embargo les falta desarrollo, como por ejemplo una mini biografía o algo similar, lo cual perfectamente pudo haber cabido dado el extenso metraje de la cinta, aún así basta con lo que tienen pues aún así nos entregan un héroe memorable, humano, moral y conmovedor y un antagonista verdaderamente odiable y despreciable, sin duda uno de los mejores dúos del cine. En resumidas cuentas, es una de las películas o quizás la película mas épica del siglo, y aunque su guion  es opacado por su espectacular dirección y detalles técnicos, es un error imperdonable que no pasa desapercibido. 7,7 sobre 10

Gladiator is the epic story of a general who is enslaved and forced to fight in the Coliseum in a low fantasy world loosely based on the Roman Empire. Jokes about the complete lack of historical accuracy aside, Gladiator has some strong points - Commodus (Joaquin Phoenix) makes for a decent villain, the camerawork is strong, and the action, while occasionally spoiled by the dated slow-motion effects, is satisfying. Unfortunately, the screenplay is entirely unbefitting a Best Picture winner. It is full of pseudo-profundities and is unnecessarily depressing, fridging the main character's family almost immediately in the most horrific way possible. Worse, the awful events Maximus experiences provoke little character development beyond making him a bit bitter. He is not the only one with vague characterization: the screenplay provides little in the way of coherent character motivations for the actors (save perhaps Phoenix) to work with, and perhaps consequently, almost every line is delivered like a speech or soliloquy even when this is inappropriate for the context. Gladiator is an alright film if you want to turn your brain off and enjoy the sights, but critics often present the film as intellectually-engaging art, a modern Spartacus, which it most definitely is not.
Visceral action and a great story make Gladiator one to watch and re-watch again and again.

I'm a big ole sucker for self-serious political philosophizing, and the line Rome straddles between continued tyranny under the sole hands of an emperor or a renewed republic with power restored to the senate provides ample opportunity for this. I'm also a sucker for the performer-audience relationship within combat sports, and this film actively plays on that with "the Spaniard" becoming a renown fan-favorite of the Coliseum-going populace. Effective in many more ways that not.

Looking back, it's been a pretty violent week in terms of film watching for me. I hadn't seen Gladiator for seventeen years, and I've wondered for a long time whether I would hold it in the same high regard I did as a fourteen year old. Especially as the last Ridley Scott film I saw was another of his historical epics, the directors cut of Kingdom Of Heaven (2005), which was boring bordering on insulting. Orlando Bloom sank the film like one of the many boulders falling to the ground in the films' action sequences, which served as a far too infrequent alarm clock for me throughout its seeming three day run time. Gladiator, thankfully, is every bit as impressive the second time round. Ridley Scott has always been a fabulous world builder, (that includes Kingdom Of Heaven) and his vision of Rome is staggering. Russell Crowe can be a figure of ridicule at times, but is on mellowed, low key, Oscar winning form here, and he is terrific. It's not often that a film with so many action fight sequences can hold you on the edge of your seat for all of them, but Gladiator achieves this in spades, and is genuinely thrilling. Joaquin Phoenix is pitifully creepy and superbly effective as the villainous Commodus, and Connie Nielsen provides excellent support, alongside the late Richard Harris in a small role. Apart from perhaps The Martian (2015), it's a long time since Scott has been on top form, and Gladiator reminds you of how good he can be.

A massive project with Ridley Scott's revival of the Sword & Sandal genre with Gladiator. This was Ridley Scott at the start of the digital age and his first colossal success since Thelma and Louise. Even then it managed to top that. It carried expectations with its overall marketing, starring one of the biggest stars in the world at that point Russell Crowe and would be the first of a handful of collaborations between Crowe and Scott. Pretty much putting Scott back on form after several financial misfires.

At the height of the Roman Empire under the rule of Marcus Aurelius, his general Maximus, played by Crowe, leads his army to conquer and secure the nation of Germania with great success. Emperor Aurelius, nearing the end of his life, believes the political state of Rome has been corrupted. Primarily by morally backwards senators and his own son and heir to be, Commodus played by Joaquin Phoenix. Aurelius entrusts Maximus with leading the city of Rome because of his loyalty, but Maximus instead seeks to return to his family after time in battle.

Commodus gets wind of this and in his madness becomes upset and kills Aurelius in an embrace and frames Maximus for the crime – sentencing him to be executed. Maximus escapes with his life and rides to find his family brutally murdered by Commodus's men. Left bereft, his wounded self is captured by slave traders. Who sell him to a head gladiator trainer, Proximus played by Oliver Reed who reluctantly trains him to survive in the Gladiator Arena. Proving himself popular with the crowd, they move to the colosseum in Rome where the now Commodus reins emperor to little appeal amongst the senators. Maximus confronts Commodus in the arena and declares he will use what he can to avenge his family, no matter what.

Even with the first scene of the battle to conquer Germania, you can get a real feeling of what you're in for. The sequence alone has plenty of sword cleaving, heads rolling, plenty of Braveheart-esque action that it's hard to look away. All the battle sequences - whether here or in the arena are particularly brutal. Choreographed in a way that genuinely makes them authentic and genuine of the period.

Backed by the spectacle on-screen is a barnstorming central performance from Russell Crowe. Who really made his name across the world with this film and clearly seeks to take centre stage amongst the rest of the cast and the drama unfolding. With Joaquin Phoenix playing the central antagonist as effectively foolhardy. He plays him as the most exceptional combination of mad and pathetic that I ever have seen and for that, it's entertaining. The film went through several re-writes and production problems, and because of that, the film is far from perfect.

There is the dialogue in this film such as the trailer line from earlier like, "Father to a murdered son, husband to a murdered wife. And I will have my revenge, in this life or the next" or "There was a dream that was Rome. It shall be released" that I can't tell if they're genius or plain silly – so I'm settling for both. There are notably CGI inputs within the film. Clearly, are added due to time or unfortunate circumstances that occurred during the production such as Oliver Reed's untimely death halfway through shooting or the remodelling of the Coliseum.

With that and Reed's computer-generated death scene, it stands out as jarring. There is a lot of Roman political discussions behind the scenes and does get bogged down with the major plot with Maximus and his revenge. There is a subplot involving Derek Jacobi's senator Gracchus who wants to overthrow Commodus to restore order. However, it primarily takes a step back and is used to move the plot forward through its three hour running time.

While there are noticeable flaws that do question its best picture win at the Oscars. Gladiator has enough spectacle, breathtaking scenes of brutal pathos, battle choreography and style that recalls the most influential films of the classic Sword & Sandal genre. It has performers that either act to the point of the camp and those that give the film a really epic and dramatic scope. I really enjoyed this film; while there is enough to take issue with it, the film is so grand on many feats. With Russell Crowe happily taking the challenge of centre stage and leading the proceedings under Ridley Scott's firm direction.

Ridley Scott is a connoisseur of metistically crafted universes, from the distorted mechanical surrealism of Alien to the bleak futuristic dystopia of Blade Runner. In one of his entries, Gladiator, Scott takes a rather conventional story about Maximus Decimus Meridius, (Russell Crowe) a general-turned-gladiator who vows revenge once Emperor Commodus (Joaquin Phoenix) kills his family and enslaves him, and crafts the marble death-consumed Empire in Ancient Rome, one likely inspired from Stanley Kubrick's Spartacus. That said, while the English director flourishes his gritty and eye-candy panache, he is unfortunately enslaved by weak screenwriting and Hollywood intervention. The story mostly resembles Braveheart with its ‘fight for freedom' allusions, the main character's family's death, an affair with royalty, and the chariot full of historical inaccuracies. In Gladiator, the script gives little for Scott to develop Maximus's character interactions and instead gives time for dated special effects, excessive typical movie violence, plot-related dialogue, and scenic vistas. The supporting characters themselves can be flat and paint-by-numbers as they resemble the tropes of Hollywood: the slave driver who inspires the warrior, the maiden who once loved our hero, the over-the-top spoiled and power-greedy emperor, and the Senate who oversee the events, but do little. Also, did we need to have the scene with Maximus and Lucius? I know the executives of Dreamworks (mainly Steven Spielberg) wanted Maximus to be a role model for children, but it goes almost absolutely nowhere and serves only as a visual reminder of, "Oh yeah, he was a father." Speaking of, how many times can the movie obnoxiously flashback to his dead family before cutting back to the present day? So, I know people really love Gladiator, but as a Ridley Scott film, it is far from his best.

My response to 'Are you not entertained!?' is that I was for some of the runtime. Gladiator has a all right plot despite the lack of realism, but the film feels overly long and drawn out. Everything is serious and silly at the same time, and things get progressively sillier as time goes on. The acting was strong, especially from Joaquin Phoenix. His character was so malevolent I wanted him to die from the beginning, but unfortunately the film left his death until the last 5 minutes and every time Maximus made progress, he got pushed back again to the point that the film was far too slow and felt ridiculously unrealistic. The cinematography was fine, the visual effects were ok for the time but dodgy in places, and Hans Zimmer's soundtrack was pleasant but sometimes felt disruptive over some of the dialogue. The action was quite entertaining, but the pacing was a serious issue that worsened the film. Nevertheless, Gladiator is worth a watch once.

Reed in his last role is terrific as the slave owner who in the end has a change of heart. He is commanding. The many stage fighting scenes are well directed and very bloody. Are you not entertained? He had a good bond with many people who remember him as a commander and the Romans side with him. This causes Phoenix's Commodus to do whatever he can to be popular but also to start Maximus. Gladiator is a 2000 film directed by Ridley Scott, the film stars Russell Crowe as Maximus and Joaquin Phoenix as Commodus.

The acting I felt was very strong especially from Russell Crowe and Joaquin Phoenix. There was one or two scenes in which I felt the acting was a bit off, but then again it was only one or two scenes in a film with a 2h 36m runtime.

The characters I personally very much enjoyed and felt were portrayed very well. I also found that the villain of the film Commodus played by Joaquin Phoenix was perfectly cast, and very enjoyable to watch on the big screen.

The cinematography in my opinion was very strong with some really great shots of the characters.

The settings were also very strong ranging from the great city of Rome to the coliseum.

The set designs and props were done really well and fit the era perfectly, from the coliseum to the palace.

The costume designs and makeup like the set designs were also done really well, from the Roman soldier costumes to the many various injuries.

The film's colour scheme in my opinion is very strong and works with the cinematography and story really well.

The film also has some really good practical and special effects from the various stunts to the way the action sequences look both realistic and over the top.

The action may be over the top, but in my opinion it is still really strong from the direction of Ridley Scott to the entertainment value.

The music I also found my self enjoying and felt that it fit with the characters and scenes very well.

The story may not be the most unique out there, but it was still in my opinion steady and very entertaining to watch fold out.

The film at points also had a very strong atmosphere especially toward the beginning and end with The character Maximus.

If there's one thing I didn't very much like it was some of the fast paced editing, but it didn't distract from the experience of the film.

The film in my opinion is also really enjoyable and something that I hope to watch again very soon.

The Best Picture of 2000 was You Can Count On Me, in my opinion, however the Academy had other ideas and decided to rewarded this Ridley Scott directed ï¿ 1/2 1/2~historical' epic. This is not a bad film by any means and it's definitely the best modern attempt at a lavish sword and sandal picture but when considering the many more interesting and memorable films to come out of the year 2000 it seems odd that something so middle of the road would triumph. Evaluating the film on it's own merits I found Joaquin Phoenix's performance entertaining, Ridley Scott's direction reliably great and the production design to be worthy of note.

Maximus, Russell Crowe, is the adopted son figure of Roman Emperor Marcus Aurelius, Richard Aurelius, who chooses Maximus to lead over his own son, the ambitious Commodus, Joaquin Phoenix. Commodus murders Marcus Aurelius in retaliation for this decision and has Maximus' family killed while Maximus escapes his execution after he becomes leader. There is a hinted romantic attraction between Commodus' sister Lucilla, Connie Nielsen, and Maximus and she decides to side with Maximus covertly whilst Commodus' incestuous seduction continues. Maximus is captured and sold into becoming a gladiator and as his success continues his confrontation with Commodus nears.

I have not yet seen Ben-Hur (1959) or The Last Emperor (1987), other notable epics that have won, but Gone with the Wind (1939) and Lawrence of Arabia (1962) both have Gladiator beaten in terms of substance. The central issue with the film was that it's central character was intensely disinteresting where great epics like the aforementioned 1939 winner concern complex, sometimes downright dislikable characters who we root for as they struggle against various obstacles. Maximus has generic motivations for being a hero, "The honor of Rome", and lacks any interesting personality traits therefore it is difficult to feel any real connection with him because he is almost inhuman. He also succeeds immediately as a Gladiator and as I will discuss later the climactic battle has very little to tension or suspense to it because we have not yet seen Maximus lose a fight. Spending 2 and a half hours with a character that is not particularly compelling can be trying and if Maximus were to have some flaws or face any real obstacles I would have liked the film more.

On the opposite end of the spectrum the villain, Commodus, is an interesting, flawed character who has sympathetic motivations but retaliates with excessive force against his father's cruelty. Phoenix's performance certainly makes the character compelling as his reaction shots during the gladiatorial fights are some of the highlights of the film. The heartbreaking monologue he gives after being rejected by his father, immediately followed by his unexpected murder, is a memorable moment that allows you to understand why this character is so determined to prove himself. The incest scenes between Commodus and Lucilla are also suitably creepy as Phoenix's gaze is predatory and sexually hungry while we also feel his need. If the entire film matched Commodus as a character and Phoenix's performance it would be a deserving winner but unfortunately it doesn't.

Scott's staging of the film is incredible as you would expect from the man who made Blade Runner (1982). The fight scenes in particular are well set up as we have spatial awareness during each fight which makes the blows dealt more impactful. The scale on which the fights occur is also set up well as we get quick exterior shots of the stadium and the contents of the stands in addition to focused reaction shots from the crowd. Each scene feels expensive and well choreographed, with the exception of a few green screen scenes, which means that the period detail can be captured and the film can serve as a visual feast of sorts despite brown being the primary color used.

This is a film that most people will see during their lives, my own father enjoyed it and excitedly re-watched it with me, whether they like this type of film or not because it's on it's way to becoming the 2000s equivalent of an ï¿ 1/2 1/2~iconic' film. I don't need to recommend this film because of that reason but in terms of how I personally felt about it I enjoyed more than the average action flick but I didn't find it to be a great film. My choice for Best Picture this year, out of the nominees, would be Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon (2000).

Gladiator is a classic film and likely the very best movie of the year 2000. Ridley Scott directs at his peak with historical epics like Kingdom of Heaven, American Gangster, and All the Money in the World. Gladiator is all class in a highly entertaining depiction of a gladiator's tough life. 

Admittedly, It is long, but the extended edition is worth the watch. The CGI has not aged well, Hans Zimmer's score is remarkably similar to his work for Pirates of the Caribbean. However, the entire film is a testimony to Scott's painstaking recreation of Rome, gladiator fights, war battles, and highly skilled drama.

Gorgeous landscapes and environments scale alongside beautiful sets. The scenery is accompanied by bloodshed of the most engaging and thrilling type. Scott's style oozes off the screen. We get a fantastic story, nuanced acting, and a glorious finale. Gladiator deserves all its praise.

Speaking of acting, Russell Crowe gives his career best in all possibility. Crowe's sorrow and righteous indignation is only comparable to his perfect performances in A Beautiful Mind or Master and Commander that follow Gladiator. Connie Nielsen lays down one of the most sympathetic roles ever captured on film. Joaquin Phoenix portrays one of the most heinous and reviled villains in cinema history. It is a creepy role that he absolutely sells.

Action and excitement are everywhere alongside heartfelt drama. Gladiator will never be forgotten. It will stay with you.

76% critic rating? This is quite possibly the best film ever made. It's right up there with Alien, Terminator 2: Judgement Day, The Godfather, Citizen Kane, Back to the Future, and other great classics. The soundtrack was fantastic by Hans Zimmer, the special effects were decent, the fight choreography was executed quite well, the story was flawless, and the writing was intriguing overall. What else is so special about it? Maximus Decimus Meridius, the main protagonist and disgraced commander who was betrayed by Lucius Aurelius Commodus, later gets his revenge on Commodus after he gave the order to murder Maximus' wife and son. After Commodus murdered Marcus Meridius, the father of Maximus, for not picking him to become the next emperor earlier in the film, Commodus became the next emperor and chose to betray Maximus by default. Maximus is captured, and is forced to work against his will as a gladiator. At the end of the film, Emperor Commodus stabs Maximus in his back with a knife prior to his arrival at the center of the amphitheater for one last fight. Despite the pain he was in, he was still able to kill Commodus. Furthermore, Maximus died at the end of the film and I was actually shocked by this. There aren't too many movies where both the villain and hero are killed off at the end. The Tomatometer and audience score on this site prove that this film is one of the most underrated films of all time.
Captures Rome, and it's good and bad all at the same time. Watch this and look at America today.

Considering the amount of problems Scott and the team faced while making Gladiator, the end product is doubly impressive, with CGI way ahead of it's time, a massive sense of scale and performances that make painful dialogue much more tolerable, Gladiator is a spectacular piece of art with one of the best endings I've ever seen.

This is what movies are all about; transporting us to a forgotten era with a dazzling aesthetic; introducing us to an admirable hero with an enticing quest; and filling us with an incredible array of the emotions that ultimately complement the powerful narrative at hand. Ridley Scott's "Gladiator" is a masterwork of both the moving image and the written word, featuring striking visuals and production design as well as an appealingly classical narrative with welcomed Shakespearean undertones. Russell Crowe's Oscar-winning performance is just the icing on this blood-soaked cake, but what a furiously memorable icing it is. Also, let's not go without mentioning Hans Zimmer's wonderfully apt score either, as one can always count on the man to elevate a truly cinematic moment into the heights of iconicism. And, "iconic" is just the way to describe the film in sum. A true masterwork of the cinematic art and one that no person should skip out on.

This movie, although not fully accurate in historic terms, is still a masterpiece. The soundtrack is fantastic and obviously similar to that of the one in the renowned "pirates of the carribean" series. However, more than that, the camerawork is stunning. Whether it is a sweeping shot of the screaming citizens of Rome, or the hazy yet oddly focused picture of Maximus's flashbacks, the image is always absolutely breathtaking. Above that, the historical accuracies that do exist within the film elevate it above the typical cheesy ancient history movies. Whether it is the depiction of the brutal slave trade, close-up of the cruel nature of man to man combat, or the trap doors and hypogeum of the Roman Colosseum, it is impossible to deny their contributions to the quality of the film. Russell Crowe does a terrific job in an almost certainly career defining role, and joaquin phoenix is equally enthralling. The politics of the film are nicely balanced with the violence of the Colosseum, and viewers are never bored. Twists are abundant, and it follows no cheesy or cliche plot lines. Overall, it is a fantastic movie and well worth watching.

Set in 180 AD, Hispano-Roman General Maximus Decimus Meridius (Crowe) leads the Roman army to a decisive victory against the Germanic tribes near Vindobona, ending a long war on the Roman frontier and winning the favour of the Emperor Marcus Aurelius (Harris). Maximus, weary of battle, desires to retire to his Spanish farm estate to be with his wife and son, but the ageing Emperor appoints Maximus as regent to help save Rome from corruption.

Spontaneity can be the greatest inspiration. For Ridley Scott, the painting of a victorious gladiator looking up and staring into the crowd, Pollice Verso, spoke to him about the "Roman Empire in all its glory and wickedness". It inspired Scott to create and direct his brilliant, Academy Award winning film Gladiator (2000). The movie is more historical fiction than based on real events. Scott originally hired historians to keep it historically accurate. However, he deviated so much from real life to craft an amazing story that the historians preferred not to be credited for the film. Of course, the final product justifies his decision. Regardless of historical accuracy, Gladiator reinvigorated interest in the Roman and other classical cultures. Accordingly, it led to some copycatting in Hollywood with the release of films such as Troy (2004), Alexander (2004), Scott's own Kingdom of Heaven (2005), 300 (2006), etc. It is often referred to as the "Gladiator effect". Nevertheless, none of those films match the magnificence of Gladiator. Scott ventured into the same genre again with Kingdom of Heaven but did not come close to duplicating the success of Gladiator. For this reason, Gladiator is an anomaly. In addition, Russell Crowe recently admitted that "We had 21 pages when we started shooting ... Your average script is about 110." He noted that "it's also the dumbest possible way to make a film. The dumbest possible way." With this knowledge, it is shocking that the movie is not terrible. It is a miracle that it won Best Picture in 2000. Overall, it was nominated for 12 Academy Awards and won 5. The wins included Best Actor (Russell Crowe), Best Visual Effects, and Best Sound Mixing. The Awards are reflective of everything that makes this film great. It has great cast that features a flawless hero that everyone loves contrasted by a vile villain that everyone loves to hate. The dialogue is phenomenal and includes many memorable lines that have transcended time and continue to be quoted. The visual effects that include epic battles and depicting the zenith of Rome in all its decadence are spectacular. In addition, the music is incredible. It captures and complements the emotions of all the key scenes. Hans Zimmer is one of the best composers in his time and the Gladiator soundtrack is one of his best works. Gladiator delivers amazingly in all these elements and is one badass movie.

â??My name is Maximus Decimus Meridius, commander of the Armies of the North, General of the Felix Legions and loyal servant to the true emperor, Marcus Aureliius. Father to a murdered son, husband to a murdered wife. And I will have my vengeance, in this life or the next.â??
 
General-turned-gladiator Russell Croweâ??s powerfully operatic speech pretty much encapsulates the tangible intensity and pertinence the film emanates and is what makes it perhaps the most accomplished historical epic of the century so far. An ode to the sword-and-sandal epics of the 1960s, Gladiator carried cinema into a new century but for its audience transported them back to the one that had just ended. Dealing with an array of aspects of Roman history including gladiators, generals and emperors, this entertaining investigation into the misdemeanours of unbefitting supremacy and its effect on one man and his patient desire to avenge the ruler who wronged him, makes for an all-consuming motion picture. Who better to helm a film of such profound proportions in history than the man from Newcastle, Ridley Scott. His filmography includes films like Alien and Blade Runner, so to direct Gladiator could be considered easy work, but by no means is Gladiator a simple film. It is a film of epic proportions transporting us through a barrage of emotional distress, physical endeavours, educational theatre and most importantly a sense of poignant uplift during moments of intense sorrow. Gladiator brought cinema into a new century with a classic of the ages!
 
The two protagonists of Gladiator deliver performances of such a magnitude that the film transcends its level of plausibility and becomes a colossal spectacle. Russell Crowe portrays the protagonist Maximus, the Roman general betrayed by the emperorâ??s ambitious son who reduces him to a life of slavery after the cold-blooded murder of his family. Legions away from his enemy and wallowing in grief, he gets a chance to rise through the ranks of the gladiatorial arena and gain revenge. Crowe truly places his soul into such a powerfully defeated man that the outcome of his acting delivers a mesmerising performance where what goes on in the inside of his character is more fathomable than what his exterior tells us. It is an acting feat when you can become the character and tell us so much about every facet of his personality as if he had been actually living a life. Around this time, Crowe was an actor in-demand and his performance as the gladiator exemplifies why. Joaquin Phoenixâ??s performance as the antagonist of the movie, Commodus, provides an equally, if not more, effective character. Phoenixâ??s Commodus is pure evil as he goes to extreme lengths to become the paramount emperor Rome has ever had; even murdering his own father to seize his throne. His malevolent ways heighten as the film progresses: from murder, to attempted incest and essentially incessant treason. Phoenix makes you physically hate not only his character but also everything Phoenix embodies unfortunately. This is testament to Phoenix who, like Crowe, put all his abilities into creating the other half of Gladiatorâ??s success.
 
Visually, Gladiatorâ??s recreation of the heart of the ancient city of Rome using extensive CGI to complete shots were as magnificent as they would have been when erected. The beautiful recreation of Romeâ??s main attraction, the Coliseum, to a fully established theatre in all its glory is undoubtedly the closest sight you will ever have of the realest thing. The accuracy of the visuals is unquestionable, but the film isnâ??t the best educational tool to use as some stories are changed or created to suit cinematic understanding. Nevertheless, the fact that this film generated what is called the â??Gladiator Effectâ?? demonstrates its effectiveness at generating interest of authentic Roman history. Gladiator pumped into the audience an increased fascination of Roman history and to be honest it still does. The term â??gladiatorâ?? is synonymous with this filmâ??s barbaric sport-like entertainment and the fact that it is in a place that still stands, the Coliseum, makes it all the more affecting because it deals with a 2,000 year-old story that incorporates places and features that still are with us today.
 
The score of Gladiator is perhaps one of the best ever to be released not only for the fact that it seamlessly blends into the atmosphere of the film so beautifully but also because it has endured in the hearts of the audience. Whenever someone watches the film, their mini review of how they enjoyed the film often involves the ethereal soundtrack. The scoreâ??s such high demand in the film-music world is particularly indebted to singer Enyaâ??s vocals most prominently in the song â??Now We Are Free.â?? The heavenly-like vocals provide a sense of meaning to the imposingly majestic instrumentals. The collection of songs were provided by composers Hans Zimmer and Lisa Gerrard and boy did they have a vision with this soundtrack as its divine-sounding elements have endured the film as a whole.
 
At the 73rd Academy Awards, Gladiator was nominated twelve times, winning five, including Best Picture. It is regarded as the best of its year and the first film to win it this century. It also won Best Actor for Crowe, Visual Effects, Costume Design and Sound Mixing demonstrating its efficiency across the board. Gladiator not only provided magnificent entertainment on screen, but it also catalysed the worldâ??s interest in one of the greatest empires to have existed stressing its importance not just as a film. It only took the 21st century less than a year to provide the world with a true cinematic classic, as it was not just a form of entertainmentâ?¦ it actually meant something.
 
Gladiator is perhaps one of the greatest historical epics of modern times, as it has everything a cinematic spectacle requiresâ?¦ and more!
 
â??â??â??â??â??â??â??â??â??â??        10/10

18 years after Blade Runner and seven less-than-decent films later, Ridley Scott didn't just return to the big screen in a big way, he brought back Charlton Heston-era warrior cinema into the present in stunningly beautiful and violent dreamlike imagery. Scott revived the old school swords 'n' sandals epics, a genre that had been pretty well left for dead, with his Roman saga about a general who becomes a gladiator as a means to seek revenge against the corrupt Emperor who betrayed him. The lost majesty of ancient Rome is evoked, with everyone in full-on cast-iron warrior mode and more violence than you can shake a trident at. Philosophical lines and spears fly freely in equal measure as Crowe and Phoenix anchor the elegant script and John Mathieson achingly beautiful cinematography hits you with colors so pretty that the blood almost becomes another accent. ARE YOU NOT ENTERTAINED??

I found this to be very enjoyable. I found the opening act to be the most captivating. It was just a barrage of great character development for Maximus. He was very likable from the start, particularly his trait as a family man above all, though he is much deeper than just that. It tugged at my heartstrings. Commodus is also an interesting and complex character that is integral to the story. The relationship between these two is very unique. I was a fan of how Commodus was always jealous of Maximus despite being in a superior position of power, and how it fueled the conflict. It's quite compelling. These two and all other characters are well acted and masterfully deliver an excellent screenplay that capture the setting and make it fun to just listen to people talk.

The fights leave a little to be desired. Except for the final duel, the choreography is rather shallow. It got so much better when it was just two people both fighting with a sword, rather than a sword and shield or another combination. They were honestly the low points of the movie.

Yes, this is little to no subtext in anything going on, either in the dialogue or Hans Zimmer's score or in Ridley Scott's direction.  You think '300' took itself way too seriously; this is probably the most self-serious epic since 'Ben-Hur' and the one that really defined the epic genre since the turn of the millennia.  In all honesty, my feelings towards 'Gladiator' are much more based on nostalgia than anything else and Commodus really needed to decide whether or not we were supposed to sympathize with him or be scared by him - never mind how it totally ignores history - but I just can't help it.  What really sells the movie is the acting: Russell Crowe, Joaquin Phoenix, Connie Nielsen, Richard Harris and Oliver Reed, among others, give it their all and provide so much more than the script probably gave them in the first place.  At my age and experience with cinema, I don't usually gravitate towards this kind of blunt, brutish, testosterone driven cinema, but there is always an exception to every rule.  To answer a very obvious question: "I am thoroughly entertained!"

"Are you not entertained?" - as Maximus yelled to the crowd. I am pretty much entertained by this movie. I could not think of any Roman Empire films or historical epics in general, that could match the authenticity of this film. I've seen the classics such as Ben-Hur, Spartacus and more. This well made Ridley Scott epic is all that I can think of. It is beautifully well made. The first thing I noticed here is the cinematography. It is brilliant! Amazing! The wonderful setting of Rome and its people. The huge arena, which is the center of the battlefield, where the event is held, and those fine armors and weapons. Thinking this is a well budgeted film. The story is about general Maximus Decimus Meridius, who is betrayed when the emperor Marcus Aurelius's ambitious son, Commodus, murders his father and seizes the throne. Reduced to slavery, Maximus rises through the ranks of the gladiatorial arena to avenge the murder of his family and his emperor. I love the story. The ambiance of this film is spectacular. The Gladiator, directed by Ridley Scott, was quite a moderate quality movie, as far as rating goes. The film starts with a Maximus and Marcus Aurelius going to battle. They win, and Marcus's son, Commodus, shows up. Commodus talks of how much he missed his father. In a private room, Marcus tells Commodus that he is going to give his powers to the senate and not to his son. Commodus is upset by this, and he suffocates Marcus to death. Commodus becomes leader. Since he knew that Marcus favored Maximus, Commodus gave orders to guards to kill Maximus in the forest. The guards take Maximus in the forest, and before they kill him, Maximus asks for a "noble death." Before the guard stabs him, Maximus hits the guard and kills all of them, taking a large gash on his shoulder from the blow of a blade. He takes a horse and rides out to find his family. When he arrives, he finds the village burned, and his family hanged (by the guards by Commodus's orders). Maximus passes out from his wound on his shoulder. He wakes up noticing that he was captured by slave traders. 
He gets bought by Proximo, a slave buyer. Proximo puts him into Gladiator tournaments. Maximus kicks butt at it, and Proximo is impressed. After this success, it is followed by more gladiator tournaments and the same amount of wins.What's driving Maximus to do so well is that by winning so many games, he'll get the chance to fight Commodus. He does well enough that he gets this chance. Just before the fight, Commodus stabs Maximus, and he tells the guards to put armor on Maximus so no one notices the wound. They go out into the arena, and Maximus, wounds and all, kills Commodus. Shortly after that, Maximus dies from the wound Commodus delivered to him earlier.


In the beginning, I thought it rushed us in a little too quickly. I don't even know what cause of the battle they were fighting was. When the scene of the audience finding out that the guards had hanged Maximus's family, I thought that they should have put more sentimental value into his wife and son in order to make that part more emotional. The scene of Lucilla and Maximus kissing was a slight annoying. I found this annoying because he showed that he loved his (deceased) wife very much, yet he so willingly kissed Lucilla back. It went against everything he was supposedly about. Because of such flaws, I'm giving the movie a 3.5/5.

I was really hoping that I would like this movie, but I just didn't enjoy it and I don't plan on watching it again.

Gladiator

Gladiator was a movie about Maximus who was a Roman general. He served under Marcus Aurelius until Marcus was killed by his power hungry son Commodus. Maximus was offered to rule over Rome after Marcus. Upon killing his father Commodus tried to kill Maximus and his family. He succeeded in killing Maximus's wife and child, but Maximus escaped. Maximus returned home to find his family crucified. From there he was taken by slave traders and sold to a man who trained gladiators to fight in arenas. Maximus did well in the arena and earned the nickname Spaniard because nobody knew who he was. He was eventually taken to Rome to fight in the Coliseum. He destroyed the competition and was confronted by Commodus who was going to congratulate him on his success. When Commodus asked who the Spaniard was Maximus revealed himself and shocked Commodus. The emperor let Maximus live because if he killed him Rome would turn against him. After confronting Commodus a plot to free Maximus arose. A senator bought Maximus's freedom so he could gather an army to take over Rome and return it to the senate. Commodus found out about the plot and stopped it. Commodus decided to fight Maximus one on one. Before the fight started Commodus stabbed Maximus in the back and concealed it. The already weakened Maximus still managed to kill Commodus. After killing Commodus, Maximus put the control of Rome in the hands of the senate. He then died and reunited with his family in Elysium.

The movie Gladiator starring Russell Crowe and directed by Ridley Scott follows the life of a triumphant war General for the Empire of Rome. It starts off on the battlefield where lead character Maximus is preparing his men for a battle. When the battle starts, arrows are flying, swords and shields are clashing and men are falling. At the end of the battle, you see the emperor of Rome Marcus Aurelius congratulating Maximus for his victory and thanking him for serving him for as long as he has. Later, in the army camp, Marcus calls Maximus to his tent to ask him to take over Rome and free it from all of the corruption and give Rome back to the people.However Maximus declines his offer and would like to return to his family and his farm.  But Marcus' son Commodus (unknowing that Maximus turned down Marcus' offer) is very unhappy about this because he should be the next emperor of Rome but his father wants Maximus to take over instead of Commodus. 
Commodus kills his father and sends soldiers to kill his family and burn his farm, and sentences Maximus to death however being a skillful fighter Maximus escapes and runs off to his family, however when he gets there, he is too late. His family has been Killed and his farm burned. He collapses and goes unconscious only to be captured and sold into slavery. It was intended for Maximus to be killed in combat as a Gladiator however he did so well that they took him to Rome for him to perform in the Coliseum. He did good there as well, so well in fact that the Emperor of Rome (Commodus) wants to meet him (Maximus was wearing a mask so Commodus did not know who it was). 
Once he meets Maximus, he is surprised he is still alive because his soldiers reported that he had died. Overwhelmed, Commodus returns to his home to think about what to do next. He tried killing him in the arena by rigging the matches, however Maximus defeated everything that was thrown at him. Commodus' sister tried helping Maximus, but Commodus found out and made her tell him everything, which spoiled Maximus' plan's on escape. He then fought Maximus himself, but not before he wounded him to try and fix the match. However Maximus overcomes Commodus and defeats Commodus, but due to the wound that Commodus inflicted before the match, he dies in the arena to rejoin his family in the afterlife.

In an age where Hollywood bombards us with films about Greek myths and Roman heroes, most of them flop.  But a select few rise to the challenge and become hits.  "Gladiator", a story about a Roman soldier turned gladiator, is one of those select few.

One of the great strengths of "Gladiator" is its great balance of drama and action.  There are some awesome fights with well-done choreography.  But at the same time this film has a great story, filled with betrayal, revenge, and beautiful character development.  However, I will admit that the ending is disappointingly predictable.  If you've seen an action movie, you probably know how this film will end.

Another great aspect of "Gladiator" is the great performances of Russell Crowe and Joaquin Phoenix.  Russell Crowe's performance as Maximus feels natural and authentic.  He fills the role excellently.  Joaquin Phoenix really captures the greed and arrogance of a prince who inherits the throne.  He makes for a great antagonist.

Though it may start out slow, once things pick up, "Gladiator" turns out to be an exciting film that will keep you hooked.  Ridley Scott has brilliantly created a film that pays great homage to Roman culture and the Roman values of honor and bravery.

(2000) FILM: "GLADIATOR "
Director: Ridley Scott
Lead Actors: Russell Crowe/Joaquin Phoenix 
BRUTALLY SEDUCTIVE!
VISUALLY ASTONISHING!
MONUMENTALLY FLAWLESS!
Legendary filmmaker Ridley Scott finally received the eight in a half pound, thirteen inch, golden statue that goes by the name of Oscar, for marvelously constructing the (2001) Academy Award winner for BEST PICTURE.   Winning five out of its twelve total nominations, the brutally spectacular and sublimely orchestrated (2000) film "GLADIATOR" impressively led all films at the 73rd Annual Academy Awards.  With a gracefully entrancing musical score, impeccable cinematography and gut wrenching performances all the way around, this critically acclaimed motion picture will be both forever mentioned and remembered as one of the greatest creations to ever grace the silver screen.  A genuine cinematic masterpiece that's unforgettably astounding and will forever be a sure fire lock into my "TOP 20 MUST SEE FILMS BEFORE YOU DIE."

Gladiator presents a rather simply story -- one man's quest for revenge -- but adds plenty of combat, several intriguing political layers, and a romantic subtext along the way. Revenge is a tale as old as time, a staple of fiction -- and history -- that seems to bring with it an everlasting allure that, in the right hands, and with the right script, and the right backdrop, makes for some of the best movies out there. Gladiator is no exception. A Best Picture winner and a good watch on several levels, it overcomes a hyperkinetic style that sometimes distracts from the action thanks to a good story and better performances that make it a fan favorite now and, no doubt, for decades to come.
The style, tone and visuals only add to the intense action and good performances.

Are you not entertained every time you watch GLADIATOR (2000)?! Because I am. This is one of director Ridley Scott's masterpieces and has one of the most powerful and extraordinary performances from Russell Crowe ever. This Academy Award-winning epic is a revenge story about a loyal Roman general, Maximus Decimus Meridius (Crowe), who is framed for the death of emperor Marcus Aurelius (Richard Harris) by the latter's ambitious son, Commodus (Joaquin Phoenix), who desperately seeks the throne. Reduced to being a slave and forced gladiator, Maximus rises through the ranks of the arena and tries to oppose Commodus in an attempt to avenge the loss of his family and the old emperor. Once again we've come down to one of my favorite movies of ALL TIME and my favorite Ridley Scott movie-he masterfully directs this beautiful historical epic and draws out so many amazing performances. The gladiatorial battles are spectacular to watch and the "Are you not entertained?!" scene is one of the best scenes in the movie. Ridley Scott does an ASTOUNDING job of recreating Rome and the Colosseum, and in my opinion the film's CGI holds up.

This was also one of the movies that contributed to my love of film in a big way because Gladiator really pushed me forward into checking out more mature films; it was actually the first R-rated movie I had ever seen. The movie is literally perfect: the action is tense and exciting; the drama is intriguing and brilliantly acted; and as far as historical dramas go, this has to be one of the best. Actually, upon its immense success this movie made Hollywood go, "Whoa, everyone loves Gladiator! Let's make more sword-and-sandal epics!" .... Yeah, we got Troy, 300, and 300: Rise of an Empire out of that. I personally don't really care for that genre...

But back to the movie that's actually awesome. This film would not be nearly as good without Russell Crowe's fantastic performance as Maximus. In my opinion, Russell Crowe is one of the best actors of all time. Seeing as how Daniel Day-Lewis is the god of acting, if he didn't exist then that title would definitely go to Crowe. He has NEVER phoned in any performance, and in every single movie Crowe hits it out of the park-Maximus would be second favorite performance of his behind John Nash in A Beautiful Mind. As Maximus, Crowe gave a brutal performance and he perfectly embodied the character-I wholeheartedly believe he deserved that Best Actor Oscar. However, Joaquin Phoenix on the other hand did not win Best Supporting Actor and he totally got snubbed. He was the creepiest part of the movie, and when I say creepy, I mean CREEPY!!!! Show this to any young kid--around 10 or 11, the age when I first saw it--and they will most likely curl up in fear over how weird and unsettling the character is in some scenes. Obviously, I did not do such a thing. That might even happen to someone older; in the end, it is truly a haunting and unforgettable performance.

Connie Nielsen portrays Commodus' sister, Lucilla, and she's unfortunately overshadowed by everyone else. That's not to say she's bad; I think she is great in the movie. But if we take the quality of each and every performance into account, Nielsen is outweighed by the other leads. Again, she's great in the movie, but whenever I think of Gladiator, Connie Nielsen is not one of the first few people to come to mind. However, that's not the same case for Djimon Hounsou. This man is hands down one of the most underrated actors working in Hollywood, but he is so fucking awesome. I LOVE Hounsou in any role he does,and he definitely had a lot to do in Gladiator. His chemistry with Crowe was spectacular, and I especially love the very last scene of the film. If you have seen the movie then you know that the last scene of the film... That my friends is a genuine act of friendship and respect. In essence, put him in more movies Hollywood! Other than him, this film also stars Oliver Reed as Proximo-he acts as Maximus' mentor, in a way, when the latter is forced to become a Gladiator. Finally, Richard Harris plays Marcus Aurelius in the beginning of the film. I'm sure you are all familiar with Harris since, you know, he was the original Dumbledore and all.

So as I said, Ridley Scott perfectly recreates the Roman time period. And I stress the word perfectly, becomes he completely immerses you in the world. In my opinion, the special effects still hold up to this day and whenever the film is on TV (well I have the Blu-ray too) I automatically switch to it and I just watch it again and again, every single time instantly being sucked into the world that Scott had made. The battle sequences though: they are extremely violent and REMARKABLE! The opening sequence itself is both fierce and stunning to watch. Maximus asks in the film, "Are you not entertained?! Are you not entertained?!!" And my reply to him is: "Fuck yeah, I'm entertained!" Which leads me into the script-so many quotable lines from Gladiator and every scene is so well written. One of my favorite scenes in the movie is the "My name is Maximus...." Scene-if you've seen the movie then you know how magnificent it is. I know some people would say the plot is simple, but in all honesty, there's nothing wrong with that. For this movie at least. The film is still elevated to enormous heights due to all of its other aspects.

But what would this movie be without Hans Zimmer's score! Holy shit, this guy is on his way to become the next John Williams (I wouldn't say he's there just yet). Can you believe he's only won one Oscar for Best Original Score-Lion King-but did not win for Gladiator or Inception among others? It puzzles me because every freaking melody that Zimmer composes for this movie is mind-blowingly good. Actually, I completely forgot to mention that he wasn't the only one working on the Gladiator score; Lisa Gerrard was also composing with him. But still, they both did a spectacular job!

All in all, Gladiator is Ridley Scott's best movie ever! You got the best performances; great direction; the score was so elegant; every action sequence was engaging; and Rome was recreated in the grandest way possible. This movie is a MUST-SEE film and it will definitely open other doors for you if you don't know Ridley Scott's filmography or Russell Crowe's filmography, etc. that well. Forget Troy and those other sword-and-sandal movies, and EXPERIENCE Gladiator for what it is. All those other movies would never have happened if Gladiator was not so great in the first place. They might possibly cross your mind now and then, but Gladiator is different. It has stood the test of time and will be remembered and enjoyed forever - 100/10

Definitely overrated, but still good. I really don't like Ridley Scott in general, but this along with Alien and Blade Runner is one of his better movies. I was impressed with Crowe's and Phoenix's performances, but I'm not really attributing this to Scott, because look at the acting in Prometheus and The Counselor, and because Crowe and Phoenix usually are great in any movie. Also I thought the opening battle sequence was poorly done, it was shaky and didn't really express the epic scope that it should have. Juaquin Phoenix, Oliver Reed, and Richard Harris are also really good.  Ridley Scott is a director's actor.  One thing he is not, however, is a great director of action.  He's not as bad as his late brother, but for the most part the fight scenes lack cohesion.  Especially the early ones are chopped into quick cuts that are hard to follow.  Despite that criticism, the tour de force battle involving chariots in the colosseum is still rousing, partially due to Maximus' direction of his "soldiers" during this scene and and a sense of momentum.  
Anything involving the senators is definitely not as compelling, the film loses sight of who it's audience is during these scenes. "My name is Gladiator."

I confess. I've never seen a Ridley Scott film before! Don't ask me why I haven't watched his films in the past, but I've never watched any film from this acclaimed filmmaker. So when it came time for me to decide which of his films, I decided to begin his career with his sole Best Picture winner, Gladiator. And while I had doubts on whether I would enjoy this or not,  it turns out that Gladiator is one of the most awesome movie spectacles I've ever encountered!

Set in the year of 180 AD, The Roman Empire goes into chaos after the death of emperor Marcus Aurelius (Richard Harris). Rome's most trusted general, Maximus (Russell Crowe), and a key player to the emperor, is betrayed by Marcus' corrupt son Commodus (Joaquin Phoenix), and ends up being sold into slavery. Feeling empty after his betrayal and the tragic murder of his family, Maximus is trained by his master (Oliver Reed) into becoming a gladiator to avenge his family and regain his freedom. But Commodus doesn't give up easily.

The film also stars Derek Jacobi as Senator Gracchus, Djimon Hounsou as gladiator ally Juba, and Connie Nielsen as Commodus' disapproving sister Lucilla.

One of my fears when watching Gladiator is that is action is going to overpower the story so much that the story will lose its epic power. But Ridley Scott doesn't do that thankfully. Gladiator is one of the most epic modern masterpieces ever made. The story, while a tad familiar, drastically pulls you in where you root for the main character. The action, particularly the scenes in the arena, are wondrously made, with Scott never downgrading the violence of gladiator matches. I can honestly say that Gladiator is one of the most violent movies I've ever seen, with insane decapitations and a ton of blood, and I was wowed by every minute of it. It's Oscar win for sound and visual effects are well-deserved. What makes Gladiator stand out is that it's more than just a violent look at the notorious Roman events. It's an epic political thriller, an epic revenge tale, and an epic dramatic tale as well (with plot elements including incest, murder, betrayal, revenge, and freedom). As for the epic stamp of approval, Gladiator definitely earns it. Even with CGI backgrounds, the film still manages to pull me in to its sheer spectacle. Ridley Scott was influenced by epics of the past to create his epic, such as Ben-Hur and Spartacus, and he does a flawless job.

Well, the direction and visual spectacle is great, so what about the acting? It's great as well! Russell Crowe won an Oscar for his role as Maximus, and it's currently the best acting I've seen from him. Crowe brilliantly conveys human emotion in this truly complex character, and while I've doubted his acting in the past (Man of Steel, for example), Crowe showcases his raw talent in the finest way with this film. The other truly noteworthy performance is the one who almost won an Oscar for his work, and that's Joaquin Phoenix as the evil Commodus. While not as powerful acting wise as Crowe, his menacing presence is still well-done, and as the political turmoil intensifies, both Phoenix and Crowe delight in sheer brilliance.

While a weak factor of the film compared to both Phoenix and Crowe combined, Connie Nielsen is still very good as Lucilla. Oliver Reed, in his final role, as he died of a heart attack during production, shows his awesome side as the slave owner (and gladiator trainer) Proximo. And in a role that I didn't expect, Dumbledore does an awesome job in his small role as Emperor Marcus.

The film also delights with its epic music score by Hans Zimmer and Lisa Gerrard. When a collaboration happens in composition, it can either be really strong or really atrocious. For Gladiator, the collaboration works. While this isn't Zimmer's greatest accomplishment, the powerful combination of Zimmer's strong instrumental touch with Lisa Gerrard's phenomenal wailing sound of stirring emotions really sum up the power factor of what makes Gladiator a strong film experience.

Gladiator is a very strong modern filmmaking experience. The revival of epic spectacle is very deserving for one of my favorite film genres, Scott's direction is powerful, the acting is great, the action is awesome, and the multiple complex layers work brilliantly. I think Ridley Scott has gained another fan. I'm still in craziness after watching the film. Final word of thought, if you haven't seen Gladiator already, do so. You won't regret it. It's one of the best Best Picture winners ever made.

Once again, Ridley Scott demonstrates his ability to synthesize complex carbohyrdates into multi-nutritional amino acids in this unique, emotional roller-coaster. While the audience, left dumbfounded and dehydrated at its must sublime segments, ultimately secures closure in the final moments of this titillating singalong song.

In 2000, legendary director Ridley Scott (Alien, Blade Runner) took a stab (pun intended) at updating the tired genre of the historical epic for modern audiences. His skill as a director certainly aided him, as Gladiator is undoubtedly an impressive feat. Nevertheless, it could not shield him from the wrath of critics and audiences worldwide when his passion project topped Peter Jackson's own (superior) passion project, The Lord of The Rings: The Fellowship of The Ring.

It's close to a decade-and-a-half since Gladiator took the world by storm, and Scott has gone on to many more projects since, but how does the film (one of the biggest of his career) hold up?


Not awfully, it must be said. All the primary players have or had better films to their credit (Crowe's LA Confidential, Scott's Blade Runner and Alien, Phoenix's Oscar-worthy performance in Walk The Line, and more), but Gladiator is perfectly-watchable, and admirably ambitious entertainment. Fine cinematography, dedicated acting, and and an expert eye behind the scenes combine to provide perfectly-serviceable summer entertainment.

In the year 180 AD, General Maximus Decimus Meridus (Russell Crowe) concludes a lengthy campaign of domination, conquering the Germanic tribes in a large-scale battle (one of the film's more impressive set pieces). Maximus is the favoured subject of Emperor Marcus Aurelius (Irish legend Richard Harris), whose old age and poor health are catching up with him. His decision to appoint Maximus as the new emperor does not sit well with his disturbed progeny, Commodus (Joaquin Phoenix, in the role that introduced his talents to the world).

Commodus offs his father, before having Maximus' family killed. Before long, Maximus finds himself taken on by slave traders, who sell him to trainer Proximo (Oliver Reed, in his final role). Maximus trains as a gladiator, finds his way to the Roman gladiatorial battles, and begins his journey to find and exact revenge upon Commodus.

The film is certainly grandiose, for better or worse. The plot basically amounts to a soap opera (with helpings of betrayal, family drama, murder, assorted violence, and incest). Storytelling has certainly evolved since the genre's heyday, but the silliness hasn't changed very much. The writing is filled with depthless, quotable lines, and the actors portray it well, but it's not a stretch to say the film is skin-deep.


One of the saving graces of the film is the acting. Russell Crowe is so-often accused of being a boring actor, or one who never looks engaged with his material, but I disagree. His style is quite intense, but he brings a great sense of realism to the (absurdly cliché) character of Maximus. During quiet scenes of dialogue, Crowe's talent is on display: He infuses Maximus with a resolve, following the murder of his family, and an unabashed dignity. It can be hard for an actor to work with such sophomoric dialogue, but Crowe pulls it off with aplomb.

The supporting cast is similarly strong. Joaquin Phoenix has established himself as one of the most-eclectic, talented actors working today, and it was Gladiator that first got him noticed. His portrayal of Commodus, as the unhinged, enternally-bitter Roman Emperor deservedly won him plaudits for Supporting Actor. Connie Nielsen is the weakest of the trio, but she holds her own against the two stars of the show.

The peripheral players, such as Reed, Harris, Djimon Housou, and Derek Jacobi (whom fans of Doctor Who will recognise as Doctor Yana from the series 3 finale) are all well-chosen, and round out a very promising cast.

Scott's eye as director is similarly put to good use. A weak colour palette is mostly made-up for thanks to strong choreography, and suitably-grand production design. The armours, furs, and dress all rest easy upon the eyes, and feel quite authentic. Battles are exciting, acting is engaging and the period details are impressive.

Technically, the film is quite marvelous. Hans Zimmer's music is front-and-centre for much of the picture, highlighting just about the entire running-time. The main theme is just-about inescapable, and while it is a fitting throwback to the epics of the past, it can prove wearisome for many modern audiences. That's not to take Zimmer's enormous talent lightly (the composer of The Dark Knight Trilogy, Inception and 2013's Rush deserves his fair share of credit), but the music's use in Gladiator begins to outstay it's welcome.

Of course, not everything is perfect. Far from it in fact, as Gladiator falls into the trap of confusing depressing tones with a heightened sense of importance. Note to Ridley Scott: While you are undoubtedly one of the most innovative director's to have ever laid their talents to production design (Blade Runner and Alien again), you would have done well to add a bit of diversity to Gladiator's palette. You can shoot as many arenas and battlefields as you want, but if the visual tone is as grim as it is, there is simply no hold for an audience.

In keeping with our theme of grimness, the writing is quite dull. Yes, yes, I love "Are you not entertained!" as much as everyone else, but the screenplay is decidedly hammy, and lacks bite. The story is predictable, and the converstaions between characters feel mighty-forced. It's serviceable for a summer blockbuster (ostensibly what the film is), but not for a Best Picture winner.

Over all, Gladiator is a solid crowd-pleaser that enjoys a reputation somewhat unfitting. The cast is well-chosen, and Scott is marvelous behind the camera, but the dialogue is clunky, the plot boring and predictable, and the visuals far too bleak. While a Best Picture winner it should not be, one can see why Gladiator is the beloved film it is. To answer the question Maximus poses: Yes, I was entertained.

Final Grade: C

It has what the action lovers want and also a political view too.

When Gladiator came out, it was like a breath of fresh air. It has been so many years since the sword and sandal genre was used in cinema. When this film came out, and won Best Picture, it greenlit a lot of films similar to it as years pass. Films like Troy, A Knight's Tale and King Arthur were made in trying to match the success of Gladiator. I think the film will prove to be more influential in the years to come.

Gladiator was written by John Logan, David Franzoni, and William Nicholson. The film explores the story of a man who seeks vengeance for the murder of his family. The driving story of the film is very simplistic and one can simply watch it and focus entirely on it, but they would be missing out on what makes Gladiator such a strong film. The film touches on themes of love, home, religion, revenge, and politics. These themes doesn't put it all on our protagonist, instead breaking it up with each one focusing on a certain character and connecting one another through it's simple narrative. Home and religion is a strong theme of the film as these are the aspects that are connected with our protagonist. Maximus is patriotic but he is only serving his duty to get back home. Religion is a layer that is found in our protagonist and the film doesn't try to use it as a way to endorse it but rather as a metaphor for something bigger. I found the antagonist of the film to be very interesting as we are given a character who is emotionally and psychologically flawed. There is so much pain and hollowness to this character and throughout the entire film, he is figuring out ways to fill it. That void is love. I found the structure of how the protagonist and antagonist are written to be engaging, showing off a human story that is easily relatable. The large idea that the film tackles is related to it's exploration on Rome's politics and the people in it. How the film depicts Rome's citizens may not be a big deal and clear back then but watching it now, I see the connection it has with the real world. I loved the idea of the Colosseum audience being very similar to the first world audience of today, both having similar reactions to the symbolic figures of our society and how we react to the controversy that occurs with these figures. Gladiator also address the politics of Rome, which I thought was quite interesting as it explored on the structure of the country's leadership and the corruption that occurs within it. The film employs this idea of the people would be better off by the hands of a senate rather than under the dictatorship of a Caesar, as the members in it would be the representation in taking care of the people's needs. The film's dialogue was good for the most part, with lines that hit hard when heard and addresses strongly on the film's themes. My issue with it was that it sounded too Hollywood, being too on point, never giving any room for any naturalistic dialogue. Everything being said sounds too important and always in relation to something bigger.

The film was directed by Ridley Scott. The films between this and Blade Runner are ones that I have not had yet the opportunity to watch, so I cannot comment on how he has progressed in his filmmaking. Other than that, Gladiator is astounding and showing that the director still has the ability to make a wonderful film. Scott's choice in making this film was a big risk, as these type of films haven't been popular in the years leading to it, and epic films have changed since it's glory days. Well after seeing this film, it is clear that the risk has payed off. I think it was clear from Scott, since the beginning of the film's production, that he wasn't going to make an epic film similar to the great ones from the 50s-60s as the film isn't so much concerned with Rome itself but instead the personal drama of these certain individuals. This approach was definitely interesting and unique as the classic sword and sandal films seems to always have a big message attached to it and is much more focused in it's production design, ambition and scope rather than it's fiction. Though the film is more concerned with it's story, the film also consists of great sequences that proves that this is an A-list production. Scott gave the film some edge with a battle sequence at the start, though not entirely relevant to the film's plot, it is really fun to watch and is quite impressive. I felt that the scene, in it's own way, was trying to match the beach sequence in Spielberg's Saving Private Ryan. There is also other moments in the film that shows similarities to other films, like the execution sequence felt similar to Kubrick's Paths of Glory. The film's tone is uplifting and the film's final moments tries to provoke an emotional response from you, and for me personally I thought it worked. The film pacing was also great, as I never felt the talkative scenes were slow and draggy; and I was watching the 170 minute Extended Cut. Gladiator was able to keep my interest all the way through. The film also contained CGI, but the film rarely made me take notice of it as it is only applied to improve the look and add little details to Rome. It allows the audience to be immersed in the world and be wowed at it's distinction.

The film's director of photography was John Mathieson. This is the first of a couple of films that he would be collaborating with the director. His future work with Scott includes, Hannibal, Matchstick Men, Kingdom of Heaven, and Robin Hood. What Mathieson has done for Gladiator was great. He creates this not so-slick look, which works with the film's brutality in it's violence. The film's image has this polarizing look, with nights taking this steely cold blue look and the daytime sequences, particularly during the Colosseum sequences, has this golden look to it. Not entirely sure what Scott or Mathieson was trying to say with this style, but it doesn't matter because overall it works.

The film's score was composed by Hans Zimmer and Lisa Gerrard. I am not sure how much of the film's soundtrack she was involved in but from the tracks that I do know she participated in, it was really effective. Her beautiful voice at the end created this spiritual aura to it which made the scene much more impactful than what it already was. I was heartbroken at the end of the film, but at the same time I was joyful, and a lot of it was due to Gerrard's beautiful voice. Zimmer's score was also amazing, also creating this spiritual effect but also taking in influences of the music commonly attached to that period of time. Zimmer knows how to create an emotional impact in his films, and Gladiator is a prime example of that.

Russell Crowe is the film's protagonist and he does a great job in the role. Maximus never seems to be a role that only a specific actor can play, as there isn't a distinctive physical quality that limits the role. Maximus is a character that is fueled by anger due to the loss of his family and home. Crowe achieved in giving the character this rage inside him, without being overly too obvious. The sorrowful moments with this character worked overall due to Crowe's acting. Joaquin Phoenix as Commodus was the most interesting character in this film, because his role is layered with so much emotional pain. The way this character was written felt very contemporary and I think that is the main reason why I was so interested with him. Phoenix came off as immature and physically weak, which was important in order to create this damaged and fragile person and it is what also made the performance stand out. The rest of the cast was also great but nothing as noteworthy as the main two actors.

Gladiator is an almost perfect movie consisting of great performances, well written script and smart direction. It shows Scott back in true from, creating a blockbuster while offering more than just thrills and the occasional visual spectacle.

Gladiator is a historical epic from director Ridley Scott.  After being betrayed by the new Caesar, Roman general Maximus is sold into slavery as a gladiator where he rises to fame as a people's champion and finds an opportunity to exact his revenge.  Russell Crowe, Joaquin Phoenix, and Connie Nielsen lead the cast and deliver strong performances.  Additionally, the gladiator fights are especially dynamic and exciting, featuring several different styles of combat.  The costumes and sets are also remarkably well-done, and create a vivid depiction of ancient Rome.  And, Hans Zimmer's score does an excellent job at capturing the tone of the film.  Thrilling and action-packed, Gladiator delivers a compelling tale.  "Are you not entertained?!"
